issue.title: "_500.tsx" Not Rendering in Dev Mode

comment.body:
Thanks for the clarification! That would be a nice feature to have if it's not too difficult to implement. In the meantime, it might be a good idea to update the Fresh documentation to inform developers that the custom 500 page won't appear in dev mode. Something like: ----- ### 500: Internal Server Error The 500 page can be customized by creating a `_500.tsx` file in the `routes/` folder. The file must have a default export that is a regular Preact component. A props object of type `ErrorPageProps` is passed in as an argument. Please note that while in dev mode, the custom _500.tsx page won't be displayed. Instead, the default Fresh error page, containing error details, will be shown. You can view the custom _500.tsx page in preview mode and when the app is deployed. ```tsx routes/_500.tsx import { ErrorPageProps } from "$fresh/server.ts"; export default function Error500Page({ error }: ErrorPageProps) { return

500 internal error: {(error as Error).message}

; } ``` ----- Do you think this is valid? I'm looking forward to contributing to open-source projects. If the suggestion is valid, should I create a PR to update that part of the documentation?

commits.message: feat(server): add isPartial to context types (#1977)

pull_request.title: feat: speed up route matching
pull_request.body:
We can significantly speed up route matching by not using `URLPattern` and opting for a custom constructed `RegExp` instead. This is roughly 150-180x faster and I confirm that in live traces this greatly reduces CPU time.

```sh
benchmark      time (avg)        iter/s             (min … max)       p75       p99      p995
--------------------------------------------------------------- -----------------------------
pattern       160.12 µs/iter       6,245.2 (151.88 µs … 712.62 µs) 161.04 µs 191.46 µs 221.21 µs
regex         889.44 ns/iter   1,124,305.9 (870.65 ns … 965.37 ns) 892.66 ns 965.37 ns 965.37 ns
```

I've added an additional optimization that first checks if we're dealing with a pattern or an exact path match in the first place. If it's an exact match we can skip parsing it to a pattern entirely, which is even faster.

pull_request.title: feat: speed up route matching
pull_request.body:
We can significantly speed up route matching by not using `URLPattern` and opting for a custom constructed `RegExp` instead. This is roughly 150-180x faster and I confirm that in live traces this greatly reduces CPU time.

```sh
benchmark      time (avg)        iter/s             (min … max)       p75       p99      p995
--------------------------------------------------------------- -----------------------------
pattern       160.12 µs/iter       6,245.2 (151.88 µs … 712.62 µs) 161.04 µs 191.46 µs 221.21 µs
regex         889.44 ns/iter   1,124,305.9 (870.65 ns … 965.37 ns) 892.66 ns 965.37 ns 965.37 ns
```

I've added an additional optimization that first checks if we're dealing with a pattern or an exact path match in the first place. If it's an exact match we can skip parsing it to a pattern entirely, which is even faster.

issue.title: feat: middleware can call renderNotFound
issue.body:
closes https://github.com/denoland/fresh/issues/1628

I now create the `renderNotFound` function outside of `#handlers`. This allows me to pass it to both `#handlers` and `composeMiddlewares`, so that it can get added to `MiddlewareHandlerContext`.

This also makes it trivial to do https://github.com/denoland/fresh/issues/1759. Please reassign that to me, because I can complete it as soon as this is merged.

comment.body:
Hey @marvinhagemeister, I've resolved the conflict resulting from my previous PR you merged last night. Please take a look at this so that I can move on to #1759.

And yes, I see that this is also pushing the handlers closer together. I have my thinking hat on and I'm actively looking at how to consolidate them in order to improve the situation.

issue.title: Subdomain routing
issue.body:
Right now it only seems possible to configure routes via path matching after the domain.

It would be nice to instead be able to conditionally route requests from different subdomains within fresh without requiring hacks.

e.g. the starter project supports `api.mywebsite.com/joke` instead of just `mywebsite.com/api/joke`

comment.body:
> Correct. To be clear, I'm not even sure how this can be done. Are you able to find another web framework that does this?

Not exactly Javascript, but a web framework: https://laravel.com/docs/10.x/routing#route-group-subdomain-routing

commits.message: feat(server): add isPartial to context types (#1977)

issue.title: Add a way to identify if the current request is a Fresh Partial in routes/middleware

pull_request.title: feat(server): add isPartial to context types
pull_request.body:
closes https://github.com/denoland/fresh/issues/1935

`MiddlewareHandlerContext` and `HandlerContext` continue to get more and more similar, this time with `RouteContext` participating as well: all three get a new ` isPartial: boolean;` added.

The key to this change is the realization that we need to capture this when parsing the URL, i.e. inside the function returned by `getParamsAndRoute`. A small change there allows us to now return:
```tsx
       {
          route: route,
          params: groups,
          isPartial: urlObject.searchParams.has(PARTIAL_SEARCH_PARAM),
        }
```
Then this is available when we build the two context objects in `compose.ts`. After that I just had to clean up type errors and add some tests.

review.body:
This is great! Thanks for making a PR 👍 

Yeah, agree with you that we have too many different context things. We should merge them all into one context type and make the properties that can only occur in other handlers optional. Would be much cleaner than what we have today.

pull_request.title: feat(server): add isPartial to context types
pull_request.body:
closes https://github.com/denoland/fresh/issues/1935

`MiddlewareHandlerContext` and `HandlerContext` continue to get more and more similar, this time with `RouteContext` participating as well: all three get a new ` isPartial: boolean;` added.

The key to this change is the realization that we need to capture this when parsing the URL, i.e. inside the function returned by `getParamsAndRoute`. A small change there allows us to now return:
```tsx
       {
          route: route,
          params: groups,
          isPartial: urlObject.searchParams.has(PARTIAL_SEARCH_PARAM),
        }
```
Then this is available when we build the two context objects in `compose.ts`. After that I just had to clean up type errors and add some tests.

issue.title: how to make routes navigation in handle of onclick function?

comment.body: The most common way to navigate between pages is via HTML's ``-element. So to navigate to another page it could look like this: ```html Go to my page ``` If using an ``-element doesn't work in your scenario for whatever reason and you really need to trigger a navigation programmatically, then you can use the browser's `location` API. ```js const onSomeEvent = () => { // Navigate to /path/to/page location.href = new URL("/path/to/page", location.origin).href } ```

issue.title: "_500.tsx" Not Rendering in Dev Mode

comment.body:
[Here](https://github.com/denoland/fresh/blob/7ad4610e3a42aba42638cbc1041b96ee58a9b29e/src/server/fs_extract.ts#L215) we check if we're in dev mode and shove in the `DefaultErrorHandler` which has the code box you're seeing.

[This](https://github.com/denoland/fresh/blob/7ad4610e3a42aba42638cbc1041b96ee58a9b29e/src/server/mod.ts#L106) command gets invoked from your `main.ts`. So you can see dev being set to false and then we don't use the `DefaultErrorHandler`.

And finally in [dev mode](https://github.com/denoland/fresh/blob/7ad4610e3a42aba42638cbc1041b96ee58a9b29e/src/dev/dev_command.ts#L54) the flag is set to true.

Sadly I don't see any easy way to opt out of this behavior, although you'd have to wait for @marvinhagemeister to have a definitive answer.

issue.title: "_500.tsx" Not Rendering in Dev Mode
SCSS/SASS Compilers support?
issue.body:
Is there any way to use SCSS / SASS and to ship the bundled (compiled) css or is this against any principle of the framework?

I do like the approach of using tailwind, but I'm feeling a hole that (imho) might be addressed about styling elements in general without relying on tailwind.

comment.body:
I was just about to give Fresh a try but I am pretty shocked there are absolutely no styles and all the examples are built without any styles just by use of Tailwind.

We need global styles, component styles, shadow dom, etc. with support for SCSS otherwise Fresh is absolutely useless.
